conclusion: Use the ideal gas law to analyze the process from state A to state B to state C.
State A: Pressure = 3 x 10^5 Pa, Volume = 2 x 10^-3 m³, Temperature = 27°C = 300 K.
Process A to B is isochoric (Volume remains constant).
Volume remains constant: V_B = V_A = 2 x 10^-3 m³.
Pressure decreases to: p_B = 2 x 10^5 Pa.
Using the ideal gas law: p_A/T_A = p_B/T_B.
Solve for T_B: T_B = 300 K x (2 x 10^5 / 3 x 10^5) = 200 K.
Process B to C is isothermal (Temperature remains constant).
Pressure remains constant: p_C = p_B = 2 x 10^5 Pa.
Volume increases to: V_C = 3 x 10^-3 m³.
Since the process is isothermal, T_C = T_B = 200 K.
Convert Temperature to Celsius: T_C = 200 K - 273 = -73°C.
The temperature of the gas in state C is -73°C.
